repnme.cdata!:
Argentina - Provincial Maternal-Child
            Health Investment Project in Support of the Second Phase of
            the Provincial Maternal-Child Health Program

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Provincial
            Maternal-Child Health Investment Project in Support of the
            Second Phase of the Provincial Maternal-Child Health Program
            for Argentina were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory,
            risk to development outcome was moderate, the Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and the borrower performance
            was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: for
            Argentina, and other countries with a federal institutional
            framework, it is critical to take diversity in terms of
            local institutional capacity into account and adjust the
            project accordingly. An in-depth analysis is required to
            identify differences in local capabilities and develop a
            strategy on how to address the specific circumstances of
            different provinces or localities. Results-Based Financing
            (RBF) can work well even in a federal system, but all major
            actors at different levels need to receive performance
            payments, and the different sets of performance indicators
            at different levels need to be aligned. Close engagement
            with actors at lower levels, including health providers, can
            make a large difference to overall performance of an RBF
            program. A strong focus on information systems (including
            for reporting and billing) is key for the success of a
            larger-scale RBF program. Another reason for the better
            performance of first phase provinces could have been that
            they had more time to implement the project. The time frame
            for second phase provinces was likely too short and better
            results could have been achieved if the project period was
            longer. If the project time frame could not be changed, then
            it will have been better to be less ambitious with the
            indicator targets. More broadly, provincial ownership and
            institutional sustainability have been growing but will take
            time to be fully entrenched.

repnme.cdata!:
Study for the processing and analysis of
            the information relating to the baseline study of the impact
            assessment of APL1

abstracts.cdata!:
The Plan Nacer (Plan) is a program whose
            main objective is "to improve health coverage and
            quality of care for the population without social work,
            helping in reducing maternal and child mortality." The
            Plan seeks to improve the efficiency and quality of health
            services to achieve better results in reducing morbidity and
            infant and maternal mortality. One of the most innovative
            aspects of the Plan is the inclusion of an assessment of its
            own impact on the health and welfare of the target
            population. This assessment began with the completion, in
            2006, of a survey on the socio-health of the target
            population and the supply of public health services, the
            LBAPL1 (Baseline Evaluation of the Impact of Phase 1 of the
            Plan Nacer), covering a sample of 60 health centers by
            province in each of the nine districts in the country that
            make up the northeastern and northwestern regions. This
            Final Report collects and reorganizes the information in
            previous partial reports. The report is organized as
            follows: Chapter 3 describes briefly the main
            characteristics of the sample chosen for the realization of
            the LBAPL1 and questionnaires that gave rise to the
            databases used. Chapter 4 presents and analyzes the timely
            filed information about socio-demographic indicators of the
            eligible population. Chapter 5 deals specifically with
            aspects of various kinds of risk factors which affect the
            target population. Chapter 6 analyzes the offering of public
            health services for birth control and infant health in the
            designated provinces. Chapter 7 extends the analysis of data
            collected from the integration of the information in the
            previous chapter through hypothetical surveys and vignettes
            to review the quality of care made. Chapter 8 gathers data
            from the main health outcomes related to maternal and child
            health collected by the LBAPL1 survey and puts them in
            context according to the alternative sources listed above.
            Finally, chapter 9 gathers the information already presented
            in the report on health care gaps from the analysis of the
            differences in access to perinatal and child health care.

repnme.cdata!:
Argentina - Second Adaptable Program Loan
            for the Provincial Maternal-Child Health Investment Project
            : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objectives of the Second
            Adaptable Program Loan for the Provincial Maternal-Child
            Health Investment Project for Argentina are to (a) increase
            access by eligible uninsured mothers and children to basic
            health services; and (b) strengthen the incentive framework
            for efficiency and focus on results between the national
            level and the eligible provinces and among eligible
            provinces and service providers by linking financing to both
            services actually rendered to the target population and to
            the achievement of the Maternal and Child Health Investment
            Program (MCHIP) results as reflected by the selected ten
            tracers of the Trazadoras matrix. This paper is the
            restructuring of the project to reallocate funds between
            categories of expenditure. The reallocation will transfer
            funds from categories, including capitation payments for
            primary health care services in the Northern, Central,
            Patagonia and Cuyo regions and for consultant services. The
            project's overall implementation progress is moderately
            satisfactory. As of October 2011, the number of
            beneficiaries of plan Nacer program was around 1.71 million,
            representing 84.3 percent of the eligible population,
            exceeding the end of project target of 80 percent. In
            addition, the percentage of affiliated health providers was
            over 87 percent and annual performance agreements were
            implemented successfully in all participating provinces;
            both indicators are above the end of project targets. The
            reallocation is necessary to: ensure adequate support to the
            provision of the basic health service package and the
            implementation of an action plan for increasing the
            feasibility of achieving the related health outcome
            indicators targets by the end of project implementation in
            all participating provinces; ensure an efficient use of loan
            resources; and support the adequate performance of the
            program and project implementation units.

display_title.display_title:
Argentina - Second Adaptable
            Program Loan for the Provincial Maternal-Child Health
            Investment Project : restructuring : Main report

repnme.cdata!: Argentina delivers care to mothers and children

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile focuses on
            Argentina that delivers care to mothers and children.
            Argentina entered the Twenty First century with nearly
            one-third of its population lacking secure access to basic
            health care. When economic crisis struck in 2001, poverty
            rates shot up, more than half of low-income households lost
            their health insurance, and health outcomes deteriorated
            sharply among the poor. The government of Argentina launched
            Plan Nacer in 2004 as a free, voluntary, public insurance
            program to cover uninsured mothers during pregnancy and up
            to 45 days after delivery, as well as children under the age
            of six. As part of the Plan Nacer reform effort, the
            government changed the operating culture of its health
            system to offer incentives for performance. International
            Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) assisted with
            the process by providing analytical support to diagnose the
            main causes of health system inefficiencies and identify
            options to better meet the needs of the poor. IBRD approved
            a Provincial Maternal Child Health Sector Adjustment Loan to
            support institutional changes that would form the foundation
            for planned reforms. As a result, more than one million
            previously uninsured pregnant women and children have basic
            health insurance and secure access to services. By moving
            from a traditional system based on inputs and fixed budgets
            to one geared around outputs and results, Plan Nacer has
            given beneficiaries more influence on service providers,
            enhanced transparency, increased accountability and improved
            public performance. IBRD continued to support Argentina in
            its efforts to achieve the Millennium Development Goals and
            its own national health goals.
